metadata.case_name: State of West Bengal v. Anwar Ali Sarkar

facts.text: Respondent Anwar Ali Sarkar and 49 other persons charged with various offences committed in course of armed gang raid on Jessop Factory at Dum Dum on 26th February 1949.
Accused arrested some time after promulgation of West Bengal Special Courts Ordinance 1949 on 17th August 1949.

State Government by notification dated 26th January 1950 directed case against Anwar Ali Sarkar and 49 others to be tried by Special Court presided by Shri S.N. Guha Roy under section 5(1) of West Bengal Special Courts Ordinance 1949.
Ordinance No.3 of 1949 replaced in March 1950 by West Bengal Special Courts Act X of 1950.
Formal complaint lodged before Special Judge on 2nd April 1950 after Act came into force.
Special Judge convicted accused on 31st March 1951 under various sections of Indian Penal Code, sentences including transportation for life and imprisonment.
State applied for enhancement of sentence, High Court issued rule on 1st May 1951.

Anwar Ali Sarkar applied to Calcutta High Court under Article 226 for writ of certiorari quashing conviction and sentence on ground Special Court lacked jurisdiction as section 5(1) unconstitutional violating Article 14.
Full Bench of Calcutta High Court (Chief Justice and four Judges) on 28th August 1951 quashed conviction, directed trial according to law.
Similar proceedings in case of Gajen Mali and others tried before another Special Judge.
Notification covered five more cases besides Anwar Ali's, all related to armed raid on Jessop premises and following incidents, involving crimes of utmost brutality on large scale.

legal_issues.text: Whether section 5(1) of West Bengal Special Courts Act 1950 is unconstitutional and void under Article 14 as denying equal protection of laws.
Whether notifications under section 5(1) directing trial by Special Court are invalid.

petitioner_arguments.text: Section 5(1) must be read in light of preamble and title providing for speedier trial of certain offences, restricting power to cases requiring speedier trial.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Preamble and title of Act; construction principles from Halton v. Cove; Carroll v. Greenwich Ins. Co.

petitioner_arguments.text: Special procedure not discriminatory on face, departures calculated to shorten trial without derogating fair trial essentials.
Discretion in State Government not arbitrary, to be exercised bona fide for cases needing prompt disposal; abuse challengeable but not invalidate law.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: American cases: Engel v. O'Malley; New York ex rel. Lieberman v. Van De Carr; presumption of honest exercise

petitioner_arguments.text: Cases referred involved exceptional character, organised revolt, justifying speedier trial.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: No discriminatory purpose shown; Snowden v. Hughes

petitioner_arguments.text: Romesh Thapar and Chintaman Rao not applicable as they concern overbroad restrictions on fundamental rights beyond constitutional limits.

respondent_arguments.text: Section 5(1) vests absolute arbitrary power in State Government to refer any case including individual cases to Special Court, violating Article 14.
Word 'cases' cannot be restricted to those needing speedier trial; plain meaning allows arbitrary selection.
Speedier trial too indefinite for well-defined classification; no objective test.
Special procedure less advantageous: no committal, no jury/assessors, restricted adjournments, etc., prejudicing accused.
Act allows anomalous results: grave offence under Act, minor under CrPC; same offence different procedures.

court_reasoning.text: Patanjali Sastri C.J. (dissenting): Section 5(1) to be construed as limited to cases requiring speedier trial per preamble; not discriminatory; classification reasonable; no arbitrary exercise shown in notification.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Legislature presumed aware of Constitution; discretion not arbitrary if bona fide.

court_reasoning.text: Fazil Ali J.: Act ignores CrPC classification by gravity; no basis in Act for classification; leads to anomalies; violates Article 14.
Mahajan J.: No real classification; speedier trial vague; executive unfettered discretion to pick cases arbitrarily.
court_reasoning.key_observation: State can pick ordinary case for special procedure, leaving serious under CrPC.

court_reasoning.text: Mukherjea J. (majority): Procedure differences material (no committal, no jury, etc.); Act confers unguided power violating equality; not minor deviations.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Classification must be based on real substantial distinction.

holdings.text: Section 5(1) of West Bengal Special Courts Act 1950 unconstitutional to extent empowering State to direct any individual case to Special Court.

precedents_cited.case_name: Chiranjit Lal Chowdhury v. Union of India
Romesh Thapar v. State of Madras
precedents_cited.relevance: Overbroad laws void if cover impermissible restrictions.
Discretionary licensing power constitutional if not arbitrary.

statutes_cited.name: West Bengal Special Courts Act 1950
statutes_cited.relevance: Empowers constitution of Special Courts and procedure; s.5(1) held unconstitutional.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Article 14 equal protection violated by arbitrary classification.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Criminal Procedure
statutes_cited.relevance: Ordinary procedure contrasted with special; more elaborate safeguards.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court dismissed appeals by State of West Bengal, upheld High Court quashing convictions and notifications under section 5(1) of West Bengal Special Courts Act as unconstitutional violating Article 14; directed trials according to law.
outcome.relief_granted: Convictions quashed; trials to proceed under ordinary law.

key_quotes.text: "A Special Court shall try such offences or classes of offences or cases or classes of cases, as the State Government may by general or special order in writing, direct."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "Where a law purports to authorise the imposition of restrictions on a fundamental right in language wide enough to cover restrictions both within and without the limits of constitutionally permissible legislative action... it must be held to be wholly unconstitutional and void."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: From Romesh Thapar, distinguished by majority.

key_quotes.text: "Classification is the recognition of those relations, and, in making it, a legislature must be allowed a wide latitude of discretion and judgment."
key_quotes.speaker: court
